Title: Is the complex function $f(z) = Re(z)$ differentiable?
Content: I am preparing to take my first course in complex variables. I am reading some lecture notes online.  They claim that the function $f(z) = Re(z)$ is continuous but NOT differentiable.  I know the definitions of a limit, of continuity, and of a derivative.  I understand why this function is continuous.  I am trying to show that it is NOT differentiable.
AcceptedAnswer:
The definition of derivative can be written as $$ f'(z) = \lim_{h \to 0} \dfrac{f(z+h) - f(z)}{h} $$ which looks just like the real-variable definition, 
but here this is taken in the complex sense, i.e. $h$ is allowed to be a complex number. $h \to 0$ means the distance in the complex plane from $h$ to $0$ goes to $0$ (or equivalently, both real and imaginary parts of $h$ go to $0$).  In order for the limit to exist, you must always get the same value as $h \to 0$ in any manner. If you take $h$ to be real, $f(z+h) = f(z) + h$ and the quotient is $1$. If you take $h$ to be imaginary, $f(z+h) = f(z)$ and the quotient is $0$. The limit as $h \to 0$ doesn't exist: it can't be both $1$ and $0$.  Thus we say $f'(z)$ doesn't exist, and the function is not differentiable.
